story: Nearly  documents highlighting the first phase of plans for more than  acres of land to the rear of the townrsquos Asda store are being weighed up by the local authorityrsquos planning department.The development, which was first revealed by the Courier earlier this year, could eventually be used for office, industrial, retail, leisure, extra-care facilities, community uses and housing.Hallhill Developments Ltd, which is behind the plans for DunBear Park, hopes approval of the roads will allow the full site to be developed at the earliest opportunity.Access would come from the road between the Asda store and Dunbar Garden Centre, as well as another road between Asda and McDonaldrsquos.Last month, Ken Ross, on behalf of the applicants, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be bringing forward proposals for the delivery of this exemplar low-carbon community, including the submission of our renewable energy strategy, to the council, along with road, footpath and cycleway planning applications.ldquoIn the recent consultation we undertook, there was overwhelming support from the community for this being a low-carbon development. story: That means neighbouring Midlothian will remain in Level  Covid restrictions for another week after the First Minister said no changes would be made this week.Speaking to the Scottish Parliament today , Nicola Sturgeon said that good progress was being made in pushing down the spread of coronavirus across Scotland.While East Lothian stays in Level , hopes that neighbouring Midlothian would join it were dashed as the First Minister saidthere was still a need to ldquostrengthen and solidy the progress made.She told MSPs: ldquoThe sacrices everyone is making are making a dference, they are getting case numbers down, reducing the numbers getting ill and needing hospital care, and so protecting the NHS and saving lives.ldquoAlthough we are encouraged by the impact current restrictions have had, the need to strengthen and solidy that progress means we should continue to take care and err on the side of caution.Ms Sturgeon said that no local authority would see a level change this week following a weekly review but indicated changes were likely to be brought in next week.That means Edinburgh also remains in Level  and West Lothian in Level .

title: 100-new-affordable-homes-delivered-east-lothian-year
story: Tenants have been collecting keys to  new council houses which East Lothian Council took ownership of in Haddington in the last few months, with a further  on the same estate due to be handed over by the end of this year.However, the local authority has revealed that despite the closure of construction sites for large parts of the year, it has continued to bring forward affordable housing.SInce September, the council has also taken ownership of seven new homes in Dunbar and  at Pinkie, Musselburgh.And during the year, six homes at Dovecot, Haddington, and  new homes at Limeylands, Ormiston, were handed over to East Lothian Housing Association for social rent.An additional  new extra-care council houses at Elder Street, Tranent, are due to be handed over to East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership.The latest handover of  homes at Letham Mains in Haddington, one of the largest new developments in East Lothian, includes two wheelchair-accessible homes.Justine Holmes, who got the keys to her new home at Letham Mains in September, is delighted and says the move has been le-changing for her and her two children.Justine, , said: ldquoWe have had a hard three years. I was made redundant and we lost our home as it was tied to my job. We spent a year in temporary accommodation and it was made even harder during lockdown as the property was really too small for our needs.ldquoWe are so happy with our forever home. We no longer feel we are living on top of each other and the kids love having their beautul garden ndash evenit is freezing.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesperson for housing, said: ldquoI was delighted to hear about the dference Justinersquos new home has made to her and her family.ldquoEast Lothian Councilrsquos programme of investment in social housing is essential in making a dference to iniduals and families who need high-quality, affordable accommodation.ldquoAs East Lothian is one of the fastest growing local authorities in Scotland, councillors agreed earlier this year to spend more than pound million over the next five years on building new council housing and modernising existing stock.ldquoWe will continue to work with developers and housing associations to stay on track with our plans to deliver the maximum number of council houses, homes for social rent via housing associations, and low-cost home ownership opportunities.Hart Builders was responsible for construction of the new council houses on the Letham Mains site.Gill Henry, business development director, said: ldquoHart Builders is delighted to have completed this first phase of development at Letham Mains and it is great to hear the residents are enjoyingtheir new homes.ldquoWe look forward to handing over the other  homes for more residents to settle in and enjoy in time for Christmas.ldquoThe final phases of this high-quality affordable housing development for East Lothian Council will be completed early in the new year.Meanwhile, Touchstone, part of Castle Rock Edin, has taken ownership of four three-bed homes for mid-market rent in Gullane.And in Cockenzie, six houses for veterans are expected to be handed over soon, with tenacies arranged through Veterans Housing Scotland.

title: christmas-tree-made-creels-created-dunbar-harbour
story: Ryan Stewart, Liam Brunton and Casey Brunton used more than  creels to create a unique version of a Christmas tree beneath Dunbar Castle.The display comes complete with lights and even a traditional orange and white lebuoy at the top in place of a star or angel.Ryan, , skipper of Ocean Crest, said: ldquoLiam just messaged me a few days ago with the idea.ldquoThey have done it other places through the west but I have never seen anything like it here.ldquoThe response has been quite good and Quentin Dimmer, the harbourmaster, says everybody has been happy with it.Between  and  creels were used to create the tree, which measures about five metres in height.Together, Liam, who fishes from Welcome Home, and Casey, who fishes near Aberdeen, along with Ryan and Quentin, spent four hours constructing the tree.Quentin felt that the display had really caught the eye of people visiting the harbour and praised the trio for their efforts.He said: ldquoThey are the up and coming younger generation of fishermen and, now with young children themselves, they wanted to bring a bit of festive cheer to Dunbar Harbour after what has been a dficult year for many people.ldquoAlmost straight away after it was completed, people were taking photos and the social media posts were very popular in the town and families were taking their children to see it.ldquoIt was so nice to see so many people smiling as they visited the harbour.

title: new-coronavirus-symptom-discovered-experts
story: Up to now, symptoms have included a persistent cough, a high temperature and a loss of taste or smell.Now researchers in Spain claim to have found another symptom, they say a strange sensation in the nasal passage could be an early sign of coronavirus.% of patients studied by researchers in Barcelona have reported at least one nasal symptom ranging from excessive dryness to a continual sensation of having had a lsquonasal douche,rsquo BirminghamLive reports.Lead researcher, Jordi Naa said: ldquoThe presence of these nasal symptoms, and their early occurrence, could potentially facilitate early diagnosis of COVID- and initial social distancing efforts.ldquoIf you have any of the main symptoms of coronavirus, get a test as soon as possible, the NHS has said."If you have any of the main symptoms of coronavirus:  Get a test to checkyou have coronavirus as soon as possible. title: covid-scotland-scotrail-offers-students-50-per-cent-discount-get-home-christmas
story: A mass testing programme of students planning to head home over the festive period is currently under way, in a bid to limit risk of transmission and provide reassurance to those travelling home to their families and loved ones.And now students will only need to pay half price for travel, on any ScotRail service until December .The train operator run by Dutch firm Abellio hopes the move will help students worried about getting home to their families under the current coronavirus travel restrictions.Students will first need to record a negative Covid- test before travelling, which could make it dficult to book specic train services due to testing appointments and the time spent awaiting results.Herersquos a little Christmas cheer for all of Scotlandrsquos university students. No need to pre-book your ticket either. https:t.co DVyuTAaNsHowever ScotRail is offering a flexible, open- ticket which will remain valid for one month after purchase in a bid to allow most students toto their studies in January after another negative coronavirus test with minimal hassle.All a student needs to do is turn up at a staffed ticket office with their ID, jump on board and head home to carriages, while thousands of services are expected to run daily to cope with more passengers.And the AA has said it was not ldquooverly concerned that traffic congestion could occur on roads, title: dave-berry-column-scale-uk-covid-19-mismanagement-staggering
story: After eight months of lockdown, this feels unsatisfying, especially since the BBC fixates on England and makes no mention how Scotland fares better, let alone where.UK Government assertions of leadership look increasingly thin as their results compare badly. Consider the countries in the table below, ranked by what matters ndash deaths per , population ourworldindata.org covid-health-economy.Apart from poor Covid performance, the table provides damning evidence that the UK Government claim that comparisons with other countries is meaningless may stem from effort to conceal their stewardship ndash particularly of England ndash as among the worst in the world.The final column gives the lie to any trade-off between health and economy: Ireland does better than Northern Ireland in both.Singapore and New Zealand have fewer deaths and suffer less economic pain than similar-sized Scotland.How so  Because they are islands  So is the UK.The scale of UK mismanagement is staggering, even before we discuss pound billion wasted on unusable PPE, or contracts  times more likely to be let to Government cronies, or a pound billion privatised test-and-trace that does neither.Makes you wonder where Scotland would be had we voted for independence in .The lsquoNorsquo argument was to stay in the EU, that our fiscal deficit of . per cent was unsustainable, that we needed Nurse to hold our hand.Covid has added poundbn to annual UK Government expenditure of poundbn.Borrowing poundbn to cover this sums to a  per cent deficit on anyonersquos abacus.EvenCovid were history by spring, the spending review predicts deficits exceeding  per cent for five more years.And this is before including an IFS projection of additional - per cent Brexit hit to GDP ndash and a further - per centthere is no deal.An independent Scotland still in the EU might have mirrored Denmark: only - per cent on GDP this year and -. per cent thereafter. Itrsquos certainly more attractive than more lsquoworld-classrsquo bluster from bankrupt Boris.

title: mary-contini-column-value-voices-grannies
story: There must be mixed reactions to this one in homes across the country: distressed heartbreak and anguish for those desperate to see loved ones who have been quarantined in care homes worried thoughts from youngsters at school whose routines and certainties have been disrupted so confusingly over the past year.For those bereaved who have so tragically lost grandparents without even getting a chance to hold their hand, let alone hug them, the reaction must be of shattered grief, frustration and even anger.Whois granny anyway  The old lady with dementia looking bewildered staring from the care home window  The cheery wie at the checkout in the supermarket, always helpful though on the late sht again  The doctor in ICU, gowned up in PPE, struggling under claustrophobic heat, only focused on doing all she can to save your le Grannies come in all shapes and sizes, all ages, all stages of le.They are not all retired, poorly or in care homes. Many are in their prime, contributing to all areas of society but all too often invisible, regarded as a diminishing asset, even a liability. Millions are unpaid carers, lsquosaving the NHSrsquo in a real and invaluable way.This generation of women have experienced a letime of unequal pay and pension provisions. Many have had opportunities their grandmothers could not have dreamed of, while others have had their careers sidelined by child-rearing, sexism and a glass ceiling that is only now starting to crack. Now, whether with grandchildren or not, vulnerable or fit, wersquore not even getting any hugs!Of course, we all appreciate the message is to protect older vulnerable people from a real danger of inadvertently transmitting the virus. But governments must value older women for what we have contributed and are still contributing. Treat us with respect and listen to our voice in society, not put all grannies in the same basket!In my opinion, ldquogranniesrsquo rights are for le, not just for Christmas.

title: covid-19-asymptomatic-testing-site-opens-queen-margaret-university
story: Funded by the UK Government, the testing site ndash for people showing no symptoms of coronavirus ndash is running in partnership with the university, Scottish Government and NHS Test and Protect to help students move home for the winter break and protect the wider community.It is hoped that testing ndash as well as limiting social mixing for two weeks before students go home ndash will help break the chain of transmission amongst students, especially when they are infected but are not aware of it, and help ensure the safety of their loved ones.The ATS will conduct lateral flow tests ndash rapid turnaround tests that can process samples on site without the need for laboratory equipment.The university is working with NHS Test  Protect to set up the on-campus ATS so that students who intend to move household over the winter break and are without symptoms, are able to get tested and asked to self-isolatethey test positive, or be quickly reassuredthey do not.Sir Paul Grice, the universityrsquos principal, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be able to offer this facility.ldquoWhile many of our students will remain in Edinburgh and East Lothian, we know that many others are planning to change household or to visit family and friends over the winter break.ldquoBy participating in testing, they will help avoid the spread of Covid to their family, friends and the wider community.Testing is available for all students. Visit qmu.ac.uk coronavirus

title: iain-gray-msp-support-local-businesses-small-business-saturday
story: Some of East Lothianrsquos small businesses have featured in the campaign over the years as part of its Small Biz , where it showcases one business a day for  days leading up to Small Business Saturday.This year, with so many businesses having suffered such a dficult time through the pandemic, Small Business Saturday is more important than ever. I hope that people will decide to shop local this year and help our retailers and other businesses to recover from the impact of lockdown and the public health restrictions they have faced with a bumper festive period.Find out more at smallbusinesssaturdayukAs the recovery from the pandemic gathers pace, Scotlandrsquos colleges will have a crucial part to play. This is in the spotlight this week thanks to the #LoveScotlandsColleges campaign run by the College Development Network. The campaign has been highlighting the importance of the sector all week, with nearly one million students in Scotlandrsquos colleges already studying as part of their occupation, upskilling and learning the skills to progress and enhance their career.In a time of uncertainty and signicant changes in the economic landscape, colleges are there for those who need extra help.However, the college sector has suffered in recent years, with signicant funding cuts resulting in , fewer college places now being available.These cuts should now be reversed and proper recognition given to the role of colleges as we move into the recovery phase.

title: hayley-cohen-become-east-lothians-youngest-church-minister
story: The Rev Cohen ndash the countyrsquos youngest minister and the seventh youngest in Scotland ndash wasordainedat Northesk Parish Church, Musselburgh, on Thursday evening.Originally from New Jersey in the USA, she is looking forward to her first charge after falling in love with Scotland as a student.She succeeds the Rev Alison MacDonald, who is now minister at St Maryrsquos Parish Church, Haddington.Ms Cohen ndash who describes herself as ldquopretty outgoing and extroverted ndash first came to Scotland as a study-abroad student in  at the University of Edinburgh.She said: ldquoI quickly fell in love with Scotland and knew that I wanted toas soon as I could when my year at Edinburgh was over.ldquoDuring that year, I met my now husband, Ross , while we were both studying theology at New College. Ross is originally from outside Lancaster, England.ldquoI ed to Scotland in  after completing my BA in the US to spend a year working for Balerno Parish Church as their parish assistant. This was a fantastic year and really gave me a taste of the le of the parish minister in Scotland.She ed to the US in  and studied for her Masters of Divinity at Princeton Theological Seminary, and began training for ministry in the Presbyterian Church .After graduating with her Masters in , she went to work in Jerusalem for an ecumenical institute that ran educational pilgrimages and sabbatical programmes.She married Ross in Edinburgh and the couple moved to Durham, where Ross was working towards his PhD, and Ms Cohen applied to transfer into the Church of Scotland.She said: ldquoThis decision to transfer was an easy one for me to make given my love of Scotland, my experience working in a Church of Scotland parish through my time in Balerno and the long-standing relationship between the Presbyterian Churchand Church of Scotland.ldquoMy transfer was accepted and I went on placement at St Andrewrsquos Clermiston in Edinburgh under the supervision of the Rev Alistair Keil, who Irsquom delighted will be preaching at my ordination. I was with St Andrewrsquos until October.ldquoI was approved to begin applying for my first charge just as the UK was entering lockdown in March.ldquoIt was clear there wasnrsquot going to be anything normal about the process of looking for a church.ldquoBut Northesk was actually the first parish profile on the Church of Scotland website at which I looked.ldquoI was moved by their expression of care for their ministers. Northesk has had five ministers in the last  years I will be the sixth. To me, this is an indicator that ministers are made to feel very much welcome and at home in Northesk.ldquoWhen I began to meet members of the congregation through interviews, first online and then in person, it was clear they were incredibly friendly and welcoming people willing to get stuck in and do the work that needs doing for love of God, their church, and their community.She added: ldquoIrsquom really looking forward to becoming the minister of Northesk and I am particularly excited to meet the people of Fisherrow and Musselburgh, whether they are churchgoers or not.ldquoIrsquom from the US, so Irsquom pretty outgoing and extroverted. I like listening to people and hearing their stories. If anyone sees me in the street, please stop me, introduce yourself, and say hello. Irsquod be delighted to meet you.ldquoMy plans for the church will be made in conversation with the congregation after spending time with them and listening to where they have been, where they are now, and where they want to go. We know there is a lot of work to do but I am personally very excited for the possibilities that are before us.ldquoRight now, wersquore looking forward to the season of Advent and Christmas. I know things will feel very dferent this year at Christmas because of the pandemic but Irsquom hoping that Northesk can continue to be a place where people can come and celebrate joy and the hope of the birth of Jesus, whether at home or in person.In her free time, Ms Cohen enjoys bird-watching and is delighted to be so close to Levenhall Links.She said: ldquoI enjoy walking with my husband. We love exploring new places together.ldquoIrsquom a keen home cook, singer, painter, yoga practitioner and an all-round nature lover.Northesk sold the old manse on New Street and the couple live in the new manse near Pinkie.Simon Fairnie, on behalf of Northesk Church, said: ldquoThe congregation are delighted at the appointment of, and welcome, their new, young minister. She will be a lsquofresh startrsquo for Northesk Church and its parish.

title: tims-tales-lady-halls-pool
story: Susan had contacted me with a story about a trip she took with David to see Lady Hallrsquos Pool, an outside lsquoswimming poolrsquo with a dference, and interesting history.She had been chatting with a friend about the benefits of sea swimming and her friend had mentioned this pool. Susan had been previously unaware of it and so decided to go find it with her husband.When they got there, the tide was helpfully out, revealing the pool. She took some photos and a film of it, but when she ed home and looked at the film, she felt sure she could see a ghostly image in the water of the pool.This led Susan to research images of Lady Helen Hall and she reckoned the image looked like her. Was it a ghostly apparition in the water or a trick of the light  Well, people can make their own mind up, but for me, Susanrsquos message made me curious to find this pool and learn more about Lady Hall, after which it is named.So we made it a family weekend trip of discovery, which usually take place within the boundaries of East Lothian even in the best of times so this was perfect. Bilsdean and nearby Dunglass are favourite places of mine, as you will knowyou read my column regularly. Despite the busy A passing through, the whole area has a fascinating history and the walk following the burn down Bilsdean Glen has an enchanting waterfall. Reaching this walk from the village is hazardous, however, as an unsafe crossing over the fast-flowing A is required, so much care is neededyou go this way.We didnrsquot have much time. The timetable of the tides was against us, as was the dying light of a winterrsquos afternoon. However, we managed to reach the beach with just enough light and time to have our adventure. Susan and David were waiting for us and we made our distanced greetings and they headed in front to seethe pool had been uncovered by the receding tide.This part of the coast is utterly fascinating. There is a lot of erosion here, and whenever I come I see new geological features and wonder about them. Irsquom no geologic expert, but Irsquom sure we spotted a chunk of ancient volcanic lava which seems to have solidied in mid flow a moment in Earthrsquos story from millions of years ago.It was from near here, of course, that the geologist James Hutton was taken in  by Sir James Hall, Lady Hallrsquos husband, on a boat ride to nearby Siccar Point, and the rest, as they say, is history.But it wasnrsquot to retell the story of already-well-known men from history that we made this trip. It was to discover a place associated with a woman who, despite her achievements and talents, was ignored by history, as most women have been until recently.It was indeed an adventure to find her pool, for we had to scramble over wet rocks to get there. Our young children took it in their stride and my youngest Lewis was looking out for evidence of dinosaurs. There are steps cut in the rocks nearby and so I suspect Lady Hall had a more convenient route to reach her pool, but we had no time to search for that.When we arrived at the pool, the tide was not fully out so it was still partly submerged, but enough was revealed of the cut rock to show the outline of Lady Hallrsquos Pool. I could just see what looked like the small steps cut by its side.Susan and David told me of the local tradition that she would come down to bathe in the sea water. Perhaps this was frowned upon, given it was the th century and she was a lady of high aristocratic status. But the story goes that her determination to regularly bathe in the sea led to the creation of this pool, which captures the sea as it goes out, making it a safer place to swim in this rocky coastline.I did not know of this pool before Susan contacted me, and I knew next to nothing about Lady Hall, she was just another aristocratic name. But now, as I stood on the edge of the pool which bears her name, I became intrigued as I listened to the story.I saw no ghostly image of Lady Hall in the water, yet I felt her presence in the twilight. The sun had already vanished from the sky and a beautul moon was rising above the sea. It was cold but calm a perfect moment for a ghostly introduction. While I had not seen Lady Hall with my eyes, I now felt we had been introduced by her story, thanks to Susan.We chatted on ourabout stories and the importance of enchantment and magic when growing up. Susan and her husband had given my family a winterrsquos afternoon of discovery and adventure. Two-hundred years separate Susan and Lady Helen Hall, but there was a connection between them. Two remarkable women from the area who shared a love of the landscape and the stories itrsquos steeped in.And now I must source the book Lady Hall ndash Lang-heidit Lady, written by another local woman, Sally Wilson. She spent years researching the le of Lady Hall and, based on the titbits Irsquove managed to see, it looks fascinating.But I will alsoto the pool. There may be other stories attached to it, and now our story is part of it too. We plan toin the summer, when the tide is out, and have a swim.That is,the ghost of Lady Hall isnrsquot in it already!

title: world-boxing-champion-josh-taylor-gets-engaged-danielle-murphy
story: The undefeated star got down on one knee in front of his long-time girlfriend Danielle Murphy yesterdaywhile on a luxury yacht in Dubai.Danielle took to social media this morningto say: ldquo  , the day I said YES.ldquoOne of the best days of my le, Josh pulled out all the stops and I couldnrsquot have asked for a better day!ldquoThank you to everyone for the well wishes and love, Irsquom totally overwhelmed!ldquoItrsquos times like this that I wish heaven had a phone so I could phone big Jimmy [her late father] to tell him my best friend has made me the happiest girl on the planet.Josh, originally from Prestonpans but now living in Haddington, is the current holder of the WBA and IBF World Super Lightweight titles.The -year-old is expected to step into the ring with Jose Carlos Ramirez, who holds the WBC and WBO World Super Lightweight titles, in the spring for a unication bout.Josh also previously took gold at the Commonwealth Games in Glasgow in  before turning pro.He also posted on social media, saying: ldquoSo she just said yes.ldquoI finally plucked up the courage to ask my beautul girlfriend to be my we. title: morham-man-rory-gammell-launches-new-wee-smoky-whisky
story: Rory Gammell, whose father Patrick also served as chairman of the Lamp of Lothian Trust, said he began to develop the concept for a whisky ldquothat is inclusive and welcoming to a younger audience and non-experts while living in San Francisco.The result was Wee Smoky, whose first limited-edition batch of  bottles sold out within four days of being launched on November .Rory said: ldquoCocktail culture was growing and I noticed that people werenrsquot choosing to mix Scotch whisky.ldquoI felt it was mostly because it looked too old fashioned to attract younger drinkers. It wasnrsquot inviting people to mix it.ldquoUpon trying a cocktail made with a smoky Scotch whisky, I had a lsquoEurekarsquo moment.Rory, , grew up in Morham, near Haddington, and attended The Compass School.In , he took part in the lsquo Hours of LeMonsrsquo endurance race for old bangers, on the Sonoma Raceway in Calornia, along with friends Sam Smith, John Austin and Wolfgang Muller.They raced in a  Mazda MX- named Nessie ndash complete with a Saltire across the bonnet and a giant lsquoSee You Jimmy Hatrsquo.After eight years working abroad, he came home via the Saltire Fellowship to work for Edrington, the maker of The Macallan.Rory, who now lives in Edinburgh, said: ldquoHaving worked in both the US and Hong Kong, I understand the strength of the Scottish brand worldwide.ldquoThat experience has played a huge part in developing a whisky that can celebrate a more playful side of Scotland.Wee Smoky, described as smooth, fruity and lightly smoky, is Roryrsquos solo venture, distilled in Edinburgh and bottled in distinctive electric blue and pink bottles.It will see its next batch, set for wide distribution, released some time next year.To find out more about the whisky, go to www.weesmoky

title: athelstaneford-youngsters-fly-saltire-bbc-st-andrews-day
story: Pupils at Athelstaneford Primary School appeared on BBC TVrsquos Reporting Scotland, parading the flag, which measured about  metres by  metres, before it was hoisted on the school flagpole, where it will remain for the next year.The ceremony was devised by Stewart Brown, headteacher at the school, with pupils told the story of the Saltire and St Andrew and its connection to the village.Each year, the school is presented with a new Saltire by the Scottish Flag Trust, which runs the visitor centre behind the village church and the Saltire Memorial, which commemorates the battle in AD. Legend tells that a vision of a St Andrewrsquos cross against the blue sky spurred an army of Scots and Picts on to victory over an army of Angles.On St Andrewrsquos Day, the Trust launched a new website saltire.scot as part of a local and international appeal to raise pound, to restore and renew this important historic site. Dave Williamson, Trust convener, said the ceremony went very well and praised the youngsters for their enthusiasm.He also revealed a last minute hitch meant the flag raising almost had to be called off when the flagpole developed a problem at the top some -feet off the ground.He said: ldquoWe made a Facebook appeal for help and local farmer and former school former pupil Craig Thomson came to the rescue with his friend Brian Paxton and used a giant cherry picker to fix the pole within half an hour of the appeal being made.ldquoA great day for all.

title: horseback-physiotherapy-partnership-celebrates-10th-birthday
story: Pioneered by NHS Lothian childrenrsquos physiotherapist Heather Falconer and MRT service co-ordinator Susan Law, hippotherapy delivers a therapeutic riding service to children and young people with disabilities.Heather said: ldquoWe set up this partnership between NHS Lothian and MRT officially  years ago wersquore very excited about it!ldquoItrsquos for children from about two to , the majority of whom have neurological conditions.ldquoWhat riding therapy is really good at is giving you core stability, balance, co-ordination and motor planning.Heather, a rider herself, volunteered with Riding for the Disabled as a teenager, before taking up a career as a childrenrsquos physiotherapist. She also volunteered at MRT, based at West Fenton.Having seen the benefits of hippotherapy, she brought her own patients from Edinburghrsquos Royal Hospital for Sick Children to MRT, before an official partnership was set up in .Heather said: ldquoItrsquos a real, symbiotic, two-way partnership. Itrsquos not just that we use their premises.ldquoMuirfield provide the premises, the horses, the volunteers and a lot of the training, whereas we provide the hippotherapist and patients. What we get is really high-quality, what would normally be expensive therapy for just the cost of a physiotherapist coming out for an afternoon.Susan said: ldquoMRT started in a muddy field but gradually wersquove become more sophisticated and when we work with physios we can measure outcomes.ldquoWersquore really at the forefront of working with physiotherapists and the principles we learn from the NHS physiotherapists cascade down into our other sessions.In addition to the  ponies that work at MRT is a specialist mechanical horse which has been named Oreo by the MRT team and has been in use since .Linked to a screen that shows scenic views, Oreo also responds to leg and hand movements like a real horse would.Heather said: ldquoItrsquos very dferent. There are pluses and minuses for both the mechanical horse and the real ponies the real ponies are less predictable, so the pattern they give you can be dferent when it comes to adapting to childrenrsquos dferent needs. But therersquos the bond that the children have with the real ponies therersquos a real emotional element to working with real horses.ldquoWith Oreo, we can push the children harder, partly because itrsquos on the spot so wersquore right next to them, and we can ask them to canter, which we canrsquot do when theyrsquore on a live pony because we canrsquot keep up!Charlie Kay, a -year-old from North Berwick who attends the townrsquos high school, has been using the hippotherapy service at MRT for  years.Charlie, who has cerebral palsy, said: ldquoItrsquos hard work and itrsquos quite strenuous but I love the ponies.ldquoRiding Oreo is not the same because you donrsquot press a button to get a real pony to stop ndash but you can get that feeling of riding a pony on Oreo.ldquoItrsquos getting my whole body a lot stronger and I feel a bit better afterwards because Irsquove exercised.Mum Mel added: ldquoAt the start of an eight-week block they measure Charliersquos walking pattern, and at the end of the block the dference in walking pattern is so much better.ldquoItrsquos really stretching him and is really good for his hips and pelvis, all the areas that need to be stretched.ldquoI notice a massive dference in his core.Heather said: ldquoTo master walking with crutches, Charlie needs a lot more core stability, better balance and more symmetry than he has.ldquoOreo is modelling a normal human walking pattern for him so all the muscle receptors that hersquos got are telling him what the pattern is that hersquos walking with. Itrsquos a sensory experience of a normal walking pattern.MRT, a member group of Riding for the Disabled UK, celebrated its th anniversary last year. To find out more, go to muirfieldridingtherapy.org.uk

story: UK Anti-Dopingcollected an in-competition urine sample from Darren Eales on February , , after a match between his Prestonpans-based team Preston Lodge and Dumfries Saints.Analysis of Mr Ealesrsquo A sample ed an adverse analytical findingfor stanozolol, an anabolic steroid that is derived from testosterone. title: joanna-blythman-christmas-food-adverts-work-effectively-women-toy-ads-children
story: Yet itrsquos still Party Central at MS HQ.Twitterrsquos algorithm, exposing the limits of articial intelligence, has decided that Irsquom a likely customer for this stuff: I am not.Itrsquos not just MSrsquos habitual, self-pleased assertion that its food is a cut above other supermarkets that sticks in my gullet. As someone who has researched the minutiae of the hyper-processed, factory products our food retailers sell, MS offerings are broadly indistinguishable, in my ingredient and production method analysis, from its competitors.Irsquom also turned off by the actual images.As Dame Julie Walters drools away in classic MS food porn style, up come the greasy, fried, battered or breadcrumbed exhibits. If I saw them on a pubrsquos budget funeral buffet, Irsquod avoid them.First, the no-chicken mini kievs, a Plant Kitchen offering that contains no fewer than  ingredients. Next, the mini battered sausages that you dunk in a shimmering gloop going by the name of lsquocurry saucersquo. Last, but not least, the chicken doughnut dippers, a food manufacturerrsquos favourite. Each of these last offerings contains between  and  ingredients, depending on whether you count every component in each composite ingredient.Many of these ingredients would only be interpretable by a food technologist. What is nutmeg "extract" exactly  How does it dfer from the actual spice  Why doesnrsquot MS just use ground nutmeg  Why does the soy-based, no-chicken kiev contain anonymous synthetic "flavouring"  But these techno-food concoctions hit a spot. They appeal to that most stubborn aspect of the British palate: a weakness for a smidgen of anonymous proteinaceous matter, deep-fried in stodgy carbohydrate casing, and dunked in something sugary.Yet my friend, an able cook and someone who appreciates good food, is desperate to buy some. By the end of November she was already worried about how she could stock up on items on the MS Christmas list. Then she found that she couldnrsquot get an MS delivery slot this side of New Year anyway. Irsquove heard the same story about other supermarket chains.How did she resolve this  By going to a physical store, buying what she thought shersquod need, intending to freeze it, only to find that because of all the bulky packaging, it wouldnrsquot all fit in.ldquoWhy did I do this  shersquos now asking herself. ldquoItrsquos only one day of the year, after all.The explanation, we agree, is that women feel under extraordinary food, and therefore emotional, pressure at Christmas. They fret about meeting their familyrsquos expectations, and weeks-long Christmas food advertising campaigns pump up that anxiety. These adverts work as effectively on women as the Christmas toy equivalent work on children.And this year, the annual festive food pressure dial has been turned up to maximum setting. Memories of bare supermarket shelves during the first lockdown haunt us. The feeling that we must, against all odds, make this a successful Christmas to reassure ourselves, and our nearest and dearest, that deep down, everything is fine.Apologies to those relatively few men who take on the responsibility for planning and providing, but this is heavy burden that mainly women feel.Of course, this festive anxiety is orced from reality. There are shops other than supermarkets, independent shops. They usually sell better food, and they donrsquot run out. There are any number of smaller producers and distributors of first-rate food who would be delighted to have our online business.So letrsquos try to keep a cool head. Wersquove had enough panic this year already.Just remember that anyone who cooks, or who has any feeling for food whatsoever, can come up with something that is better quality and more delicious than those over-hyped supermarket reheats that never look, or taste, anywhere near as good as the enticing picture on the box.

title: scottish-panoramas-iconic-red-deer-glenshee
story: The place is Glenshee, on the edge of the Cairngorms National Park. Itrsquos known in Gaelic as Gleann Shith, the Glen of the Fairies, but itrsquos also the glen of the red deer, which graze on grasses, sedges, heather and woody plants and live in the Cairngorms in large herds. Except for during mating season the deer tend to stay in single sex groups and this image shows four stags foraging for food on a hillside which already has its first covering of snow, their antlers picked out in silhouette against the winter sky.If the image seems familiar or evokes a response therersquos a reason. Just under  years ago, in , the English painter Edwin Landseer journeyed north from his home on London to enjoy the first of several visits to the Highlands. It was during one of these that he made the sketch that would become his most famous work: The Monarch Of The Glen, completed in  as part of a three-painting commission for what was euphemistically known as the Refreshment Room at the House Of Lords. When the ermine-clad peers refused to stump up the pound fee, The Monarch Of The Glen passed through a iety of private hands and eventually ended up in the Scottish National Gallery. By then it had become roaringly popular and emblematic of what you might call the ldquobiscuit tin view of Scotland.Landseerrsquos stag has  points, or tines, to its antlers, making it a Royal stag rather the Monarch iety, which tend to have  points . An Imperial stag, meanwhile, would have  points. None of ours look like they can even muster , though they are no less impressive a sight for it.That said, you might smell them before you see them, especiallythey are present in numbers. Thatrsquos what happened to mountaineer Brian Shackleton, a descendent of polar explorer Sir Ernest Shackleton, while walking in Glenshee in . Catching a ldquovery, very strong smell of deer as he crested a ridge he found himself looking at a grazing herd of between  and  deer. There were so many there was steam rising off them, he told a local newspaper.Deer produce considerable amounts of methane as well as steam, and large grazing herds can have a detrimental effect on plant le and bioersity. Accordingly, there are increasing calls for legally enforceable culls. Edwin Landseerrsquos romantic th century vision of the Scottish landscape is one thing, maintaining the living mountain in the teeth of st century environmental collapse quite another.

title: food-tricks-trade-former-bake-off-winner-john-whaite
story: John Whaite, winner of the  series, set up his quaint cookery school in Lancashire in . A small group of us gatherin the delectable converted barn, whipping up chocolate silk pies with pear and caramel, cherry crumble blondies and the best carrot cake Ive ever tasted. Here are some of the things I learned on the way.... If your cake batter curdles - or any mixture splits when using fat, pop it over a bain-marieand whisk vigorously. If youre using a KitchenAid, warm the bowl with a blow torch, and then whisk. Do this quickly though - you dont want your mixture lurking over the hot water for too long.. When putting pastry in the fridge, flatten it into a disk, rather than balling it into a boulder, so you dont have to turn a big ball into a flat disk later.. If your pastry shrinks in the oven, it means youve overworked it. Start again!. Use a toothbrush to create pretty splashes when youre icing a cake.. Roast damsons in the oven and use them to make jam. The stones squeeze out easily after being roasted, and you can use the juice in your cake frosting .. Use a hot kne to slice your cakes up - this works especially well for fridge-cooled gooey brownies. Warm your kne up by dipping it in hot water.. To stop an icing-sugar dust cloud, mix the butter and icing sugar with the paddle by hand, pressing it down, before turning your mixer on.. Use egg yolk, a tiny splash of water and a pinch of salt for the perfect egg wash.. Use acrylic rods when rolling out pastry to ensure its the perfect thickness all the way through.. Always leave scone dough to rest - it takes  mins for the baking powder to get to work, to relax the gluten and give you soft, pillowy scones.. Weigh your liquid ingredients - jug measurements arent always right.. When you make pastry or dough, mix it in your mixer to start with, but bring it together by hand for a perfectly smooth consistency.. When making sweet pastry, use sugar not icing sugar. Icing sugar can make the pastry rubbery.. Use white sugar when making caramel, not golden, because its more refined, so there are fewer bits in it that might crystallise.. Use rice for blind baking, not baking beans - its cheaper!. When making carrot cake , grate your carrots into a clean tea towel and squeeze out any excess water. Sprinkle a bit of sugar on the grated carrot to help absorb even more.. Use paperclips to secure your baking paper to the pans - this stops it blowing around in a fan oven.. If your pastry breaks when you roll it out, simply give it a very quick knead, then put plenty of flour down and roll it out again. Have a pastry brush on hand to dust off any excess flour.. Le is too short to make your own puff pastry. Use ready-rolled, so long as its all-butter.For more information on John Whaites Kitchen, or to book a cookery course, visit johnwhaiteskitchen.

title: fidelma-cook-coming-new-dawn-suffused-happiness-give-thanks
story: I electronically raise my shutters and myself, and look out to the still darkness and watch it gradually change content with its progress.Nurses come and go in a choreographed routine ndash pills, thermometer reading and then breakfast of good bread, butter, jam and cold, cold orange juice. Finally, the door closes again and I am left with my peace.By now, as is often common in these months, the sky is showing its blue, blue mantle with shafts of sunlight turning the now lush grass of winter to sparkling promise of further late growth.And my mind is calm ordered even not a dozen dferent, dfering thoughts and conclusions fighting away with each other. All seems logical, right and working to a good, positive purpose.I have started walking again ndash my Ferrari Zimmer parked up but there in case I need the additional security and the joy of unaided steps on so much stronger legs is almost beyond words, leading to pleasurable sighs instead.Then I think of Las Molieres and how there I would be manually opening and clipping back the shutters. Often, I would stand at the open French windows, shivering slightly in the mist which seemed a daily morning occurrence where we are.I would range my eyes from the distant village church glimpsed through the now bare upright arms of the woods over to the crossroads ing into the valley or turning towards Lavit.And I would listen to heavy silence broken only by the rush of Cesarrsquos body racing back from his check of the land that all had been well in the night.And that mist, like the hospital darkness, would dissipate toohellipslyly sneaking away to let the weak light come forth and the sky show its glory.Then, vaguely discontented and already bored, I would make a cappuccino from a sachet, open the computer and begin the morning read of the papers.Ah,I had only known what was rushing towards me, already multiplying and festering in my cells, how much more would I have relished such mundanities.Perhaps thatrsquos why I now waken with such surreal happiness because now I know.The serenity and the certitude grow less and less as afternoon turns into frighteningly early evening and darkness falls and I press the shutters for theirdownward journey.It depends what the next day holds as to how quickly the mood evaporates and the demonsto bicker and debate in my brain.Rosemary Gorings Country Le: steering a safe route towards winterAfter a break, the doctors are to give me immunotherapy tomorrow and I dread what may follow with a visceral fear. Towards the end of the month, now having been measured for the mask, I will have ten consecutive days of preventative radiation focused on the brain. That fills me with fear too in case something is lsquolostrsquo in the power of the radiation.And they now no longer feel I should be in London. They believe I should continue and end my treatment here so that there can be no risk of any delay at the other end.Logically I agree with them until I speak to my son who wants to come, sweep me up and into the Marsden who he says will immediately continue treatment.But Irsquove lived too long not to know that le does not always run on linear lines and much is out with our control at times. Pierce feels betrayed by me I think although I assure him I am committed to Londonhellipwhen able.I understand ndash he has worked so hard to ensure my acceptance there and has such faith in them, not so much in France. He is filled with impotent frustration and sees me dying faster than I still see me living.Unfortunately, these conversations take place mid evenings when I begin to ebb and nothing seems certain or too hopeful and he leaves me with too many what s for a restful run up to sleep.Today too I went across to the unit I must move to and depression has descended with the night. An older building, the rooms are smaller and uglier, the corridors narrow and scuffed and I felt Irsquod been cast out of Paradise.But after treatments I need the presence of nursing care day and night and for this, the way the French system works, I will have to pay  euros a month.The same high standards and protocols apply the food comes from the same kitchen and my boiled eggs are safe. But the nursing teams are dferent and I will leave behind the great kindness of those who have cared for me all these months.The ones who know my foibles the necessity of plugs and placements for my Mac and phone the chair or table to hold them all.However, for now, for a few hours on the good days, starting with the coming of the dawn, I am suffused with happiness and for that I give thanks. title: notes-africa-funny-side-dreaded-vd
story: Entering the tawdry premises in Glasgowrsquos Cowcaddens one wintry evening, the nurse behind a small desk didnrsquot raise her head at my greeting. Thrusting a bottle in my direction, she gestured towards a cubicle.ldquoOver there, Jimmy. Pee in the pot. Trousers aff. Pants aff. Wait for the doctor mannie.ldquoBut Irsquom from the university. Irsquove come to..."ldquoYou yins at uni are as bad as everyone , sonny. Uni or not, itrsquos nae odds tae me ndash just pee in the pot.In Swaziland, my introduction to gonorrhoea was courtesy of a student nurse who was translating for me in the hospitalrsquos Outpatient clinic.ldquoThis is babe Sikhondze. He is a reverend, she lisped, indicating a fresh-faced young man with a big cross slung round his neck. ldquoHis problem is lsquodroprsquo."ldquoBeg your pardon ldquoHersquos got lsquodroprsquo, doctor ndash from his pipe, she added helpfully, using the slang term for the Holy Onersquos appendage.This was the first time Irsquod heard the local description for the diseasersquos presentation as a bead of pus. Faced with the visible evidence of a jolly romp, Africarsquos sufferers behave in exactly the same way as their European cousins. Asked why theyrsquove come to see you and theyrsquore off ndash vague headaches, itchy eyes, a sore back, on they ramble until just about to take their leave when they would mutter sotto voce about lsquoloss of powerrsquo. Their problem is, in fact, excess of power but channelled up a creek where their paddle has got itself barnacled.Nowadays I find it kinder to short-circuit proceedings. The consulting room door bursts open and in he breezes, smiling for no reason, brushing an imaginary bit of dust off his shirt, asking how you are, then replying on your behalf. He will make eye contact with the nurse and suggest she leaves.ldquoLukhele...! you cut in.ldquoYes, doc ldquoYoursquove got lsquodroprsquo, havenrsquot you "Who  Me You indicate that there are now only two of you at this confessional.ldquoWell ndash ah ndash yes ndash no! How did you... ldquoLukhele, trousers off. Pants off. Pee in the pot...Some patients are not as reticent. Not long ago I was minding my own business selecting sweet potatoes and pawpaws in the village market when a taxi-driver greeted me. I ed his good wishes but was unsettled at seeing him unzip his trousers. Would I mind, he asked, giving him an opinion on a little local dficulty that had been worrying him  The stalls were crowded but none of the passers-by appeared concerned or upset that Mfanasibili was now trying to find the exact spot on his pride and joy for a professional inspection. For a moment, I tried to visualise this consultation taking place in Fortnum and Masonrsquos cold meat and pate emporium off Oxford Street in London. Would their customers have been as understanding, let alone the magistrate the following morning Mars and Venus were uncomfortably in evidence from the very first day working in Kampala when our medical superintendent and specialist physician, Sister Veronica Cotter, introduced us to two dozen fellow males in St Patrickrsquos ward at Nsambya Hospital. All had large red rubber catheters protruding from their lower bellies, the consequence of repeated attacks of gonorrhoea sustained in the line of duty tasting the fruits of the Pearl of Africa.Veronica gave me a knowing look and raised one eyebrow.ldquoAh, yes, lsquotis a dangerous place, Uganda, David. Beautul but ndash eh ndash dangerous!I felt a distinct shrivelling of my own nether regions. Imagine a St Patrickrsquos man trying to be romantic ndash at the crucial moment, hersquod need the services of a plumber or a hydraulic engineer.Dr David Vost studied medicine at Glasgow University and is currently working at a hospital in Swaziland. He and his family live on a small farm in Northern Uganda near the Albert Nile. davidvostsz@gmail

title: olive-mabel-andrew-cotter-climbing-scottish-mountains
story: Where is it Braeriach in the Cairngorms.Why do you go there Braeriach is representative of all Scottish mountains for me. But I thought I should probably try to be more specic. Ive chosen Braeriach and the mountains around the Lairig Ghru because the area is, in the winter at least, open and wild and above all quiet. A total escape from all man-made things.How often do you go Not nearly often enough. I live in Cheshire and would dearly love to be further north, but practically it makes more sense to be more central with easier access to London or an airport. As soon as the first proper snows come and travel is allowed, Ill be back.How did you discover it My dad wasa keen hillwalker. Even though I grew up in the least bumpy part of Scotland, in Troon, the mountains were always a favourite destination. And they became that much more important once I had moved down to London because they were a very necessary antidote to big city le.Whats your favourite memory One of the reasons I chose Braeriach was that a couple of years ago I experienced one of my most joyful days in the mountains, climbing it along with Sgor an Lochain Uaine and Cairn Toul, in the snow, with my dogs, Olive and Mabel. It was  miles, ,ft feet of climbing and just me and the fur sherpas for  hours. Total bliss.Andrew Cotters dogs Olive and Mabel on Braeriach in the Cairngorms. Picture: Andrew CotterWho do you take Olive and Mabel. My partner Caroline loves long walks but not necessarily ones which involve a gradient. And certainly not snow.: great Scottish festive books, films, TV shows and songs Quite often I end up climbing with a chap called Iain Cameron, who is a published snow expert. We talk about things like wind slab avalanches while the dogs eat sheep droppings.What do you take More gear than you think possible to carry. But, on serious note, it is not a place to be caught lacking in clothing or equipment. And Im a sucker for all the gear. The people at Tiso, the outdoor store in Perth, rub their hands when they see me coming.What do you leave behind Nothing. Litter is a national disgrace in Scotland and the UK as a whole. Of all the countries I have visited, I have never seen anywhere  where it seems to be a problem on such a scale.: great Scottish festive books, films, TV shows and songs I find it infuriating and baffling that people who go to visit the beauty of the countryside will be so selfish as to then spoil it. Leave nothing but footprints. And paw prints.Sum it up in five words.Cold. Vast. Wild. Quiet. Beautul.What travel spot is on your post-lockdown wish list To get back to Australia and visit Carolines brother Johnny and his family. And get some Vitamin D. But Ill miss the dogs.Olive, Mabel And Me: Le and Adventures With Two Very Good Dogs by Andrew Cotter is published by Black  White, priced pound

title: letters-worlds-glamorous-man-supped-pints-crumbling-cowcaddens-pub
story: The project was the brainchild of the Scottish industrialist, Sir Iain Stewart. Connery and Stewartwere golfing buddies. The gregarious Stewart, with a seat on the main board, took the idea to Scottish Television.The fact he lacked a "directorrsquos ticket" issued by the Association of Cinematograph Television and Allied Techniciansthreatened the project for a time ironic, perhaps, when you consider the subject matter was the need to improve worker-management relations throughout industry.The problem was solved by STV assigning staff director Bryan Izzard, a larger-than-le character with a history in light entertainment, to accompany Connery on his mission.At the end of each dayrsquos shoot, the man known to more than half the world as James Bond could be found, supping pints, in a crumbling building in Cowcaddens, a mile or more to the north. Dohertyrsquos, the pub where Connery parked his custom-built Jensen Interceptorhad, as its regular clientele, an assortment of people who lived nearby, as well as workers from the old Buchanan Street railway yards, off-duty policemen, and a real hybrid crewfrom Scottish Television across the road.Thanks to the location of the TV studios and the impeccable manners of its gentlemanly owner, Hugh Doherty, well-known faces were a regular sight in Dohertyrsquos. Except, of course, this was no ordinary celebrity ndash this was Sean Connery, perhaps the most glamorous, envied man in the world.How did Dohertyrsquos regular clientele react  Following their initial surprise at finding the man who was James Bond drinking in their midstno-one appeared to find his presence in any way remarkable.For some, of course, it might have been dficult to reconcile the handsome star of the Bond movies, in his designer clothes, with the casually dressed figure seated at the bar.Gone was the immaculate clean-cut image made famous by the worldrsquos most glamorous spy. In its place was a balding figure, badly in need of a haircut, sporting a large Mexican-style moustache. One man said the Connery with whom he exchanged a few words in Dohertyrsquos looked more "like Viva Zapata than James Bond".Connery, it must be said, was polite, good humoured and not unapproachable, within the bounds of acceptable pub behaviour. Amazinglyno-one betrayed his whereabouts to the tabloids.Russell Galbraith, Formerly Assistant Controller of Programmes, Scottish Television, Bearsden.GOOD SPELL FOR INVERURIEIT is interesting that Inverurie has Scotlandrsquos fastest broadband speeds . It is obviously a welcome accolade for the town to have this recognition as being at the top in certain aspects of modern communications.What is perhaps less well known in terms of communications is it is reported that in the th century, when postal services were growing signicantly , the council in the town decided that the name to be used for Council business should be changed from "Inverury" to "Inverurie", because so many letters addressed "Inverury" were going to Inverary in Argyll. Support for the change was derived from the fact that it was considered that "Inverurie" was the ancient spelling and the public were asked to adopt this spelling.Sometimes, the answer to the question "whatrsquos in a name " is "quite a lot".Ian W Thomson, Lenzie.PARK PERKSBOTH pictures of Glasgow families enjoying the Botanic Gardens environs in  and occasion my comment. Without exception the citizens highlighted were well clad with not a hint of the extreme poverty which beset Glasgow in that era. Not a sign of any tenement back court weans strutting around in ill-fitting wellies or proudly hurling their home-made timber bogies around the park.Perhaps Botanic parkies had instructions to exclude such citizens, albeit they and their families resided in teeming overcrowded tenements adjunct the park perimeter. Thankfully these aspects of times past no longer apply.Allan C Steele, Gfnock.TRAM LINESI MUST take issue with John Dunlop and Ian Wilsonregarding your photograph of the trams at Glasgow Cross. At the risk of being pedantic, it is apparent that the gentleman is picking up his penny after the tram had run over it ndash not placing it. The trolley bar on the tram is sloping towards the camera, the destination board reads "Clydebank" and the thing is heading west.I think it is important to get these things right, especially as there isnrsquot much  happening at the moment.Simon Paterson, Glasgow G.I NOTE the correspondence on people laying pennies on tram tracks. Here in Aberdeen, our tramways department ensured that all pennies laid on rails were added to the city coffers.We used glue on the wheels.Gordon Casely, Crathes.

title: ally-mclaws-can-stop-world-not-santa-suit
story: The virus has infected  million people and killed more than one and a half million.At a more personal level the coronavirus put paid to my daughters big wedding plans for May .One grand-daughter lost out on her exciting first steps into the world of zoology and veterinary medicine when a secondment to Edinburgh Zoo was scrapped. Now shersquos grateful for just a few hours when possible as a restaurant waitress.Then therersquos the impact on my pals two pubs in Govan which havenrsquot been able to turn a single penny of profit in recent months ndash Covid might even do for them altogethersomething doesnrsquot change very quickly.And, of-course, itrsquos stopped me from seeing kids and grandkids. Itrsquos fair to say my health-status of battling lung cancer would have put paid to a lot of the more adventurous stuff Irsquod normally have got involved in... but some hugs and having a laugh together or going to watch them horse riding or going for a beach walk with the dogs would certainly have been on the cards.Despite rules allowing family gatherings at Christmas the risks to me as a cancer patient have even stopped that from happening...but it canrsquot stop me going up the loft and digging out my Santa suit!And it wonrsquot stop me padding up my skinny frame with cushionsand pulling it on for a video call to the younger grankids.As you might have guessed from my surname ndash this ldquoScottish Santa thing is a bit of tradition in my family. My nickname at school was Santa and having gone through primary and secondary school with my we Laura itrsquos perhaps understandable that she still refers to meas ldquomy Santa.When my youngest son Blair was in the RAF and serving in Afghanistan during the Christmas of  he wrote askingIrsquod send him out a Santa suit so he could deliver the parcels that arrived at the military base.And then therersquos grandson Bailey Mclaws who was born on Christmas Day! Hersquoll surely keep the tradition going through the next couple of generations.So thatrsquos something Covid hasnrsquot stopped this yearhellipand hopefully during  we can thank all the wonderful healthcare scientists who have worked so brilliantly and collaboratively to develop vaccines that will stop this virus in its tracks.Ally McLaws is managing director of the McLaws Consultancy, specialist in business marketing and reputation management. All back copies of this column are available at www.mclawsconsultancy

title: Iain Macwhirter  The loss of BiFab is a national humiliation
story: BiFab should have had just the right skills and know-how to move into the renewable energy age by building turbine jackets for the wind farms that are bristling around Scotlands coast. But it was not to be.Last week, the Scottish Government effectively signed BiFabs death warrant. This in the very week that Boris Johnson announced a dramatic further increase in targets for the reduction of UK emissions, most of which will be achieved through offshore wind.:Over poundm of taxpayers money face being lost as ministers rule out nationalisation of collapsed BiFabSo much for the green jobs revolution. Scotlands major hope for getting a poundbn slice of the renewable energy action has gone south.This is a major political scandal, and rightly condemned by a vote of the Scottish Parliament last week. BiFab has not one but two major windfarms on its very Fe doorstep: the Seagreen array off Angus and Neart na Goailthe . These poundbn projects together had contracts out for at least  full Methil jackets.It beggars belief that BiFab was unable to get any of this work, despite a poundm bung to its Canadian owners JV Driver.Instead, the French state-owned energy giant, EDF, will build them mostly in Asian yards and have them dragged , miles by diesel tugs.A jaunty-sounding Fiona Hyslop, the Scottish Economy Secretary, told Good Morning Scotland that her hands were tied by Brussels competition rules. Too bad. Lessons to be learned etc.. But arent we supposed to be leaving the EU  Why would they have any say in the matter It would be ldquonaive, she replied, to believe that these state aid restrictions will not continue in some form. Well,so, why did the Scottish Government pony up so much cash in the first place If Scotland is the Saudi Arabia of renewables, BiFabs loss is surely a national humiliation. No other country would countenance such industrial defeatism, certainly not Norway which now has a substantial stake in renewables.The Scottish Government has merely acquired a track record for pouring public money into lost causes from Prestwick Airport to Ferguson Marine. This confirms that civil servants and politicians are just not very good at business. They dont understand it.They leap into action chasing favourable headlines by promising cash injections, only to stand aside thereafter as it gets burnt by private sector companies whorsquoll never turn away free money.What Scotland lacks is a coherent overall industrial strategy, or any industrial strategy. We hear homilies about building back better and making the economy work ldquofor people not profit instead of just making it work.The Scottish Government had the option of taking over BiFab at next to no cost, but declined on the basis that a nationalised BiFab would still be hamstrung by European competition rules.This is a reminder that however much SNP likes to talk left and talk green, at least when trying to enlist support at elections time, it is no more socialist than New Labour or even Boris Johnson.:Anger as part Scottish Government-owned BiFab files for administrationPerhaps less so, now that the Tory government has essentially taken half the British workforce onto the public payroll and borrowed more money faster than even Jeremy Corbyn intended.No one wants to live in a communist state, but we have the right to expect the Scottish Government to have an activist industrial policy that puts Scotland first.That may sound like Donald Trump, but he wasnt wrong about the need to challenge corporate globalisation and labour arbitrage ndash that is, companies exporting jobs to low-wage countries and destroying the domestic industrial base.Ms Hyslop lamented that Scotland couldnt compete with workers being paid pound. an hour in China or Indonesia. But it beggars belief that Scotland couldnt secure some guarantees from EDF that local, sustainable industry should be part of the supply chain. The Scottish Government has many planning powers and licenses these mega windfarms in the first place.Every year Nicola Sturgeon makes inflated promises abut a green jobs revolution. But delivery has been pretty dismal in the decade since ministers first started spouting this boosterist greenwash. As The Herald reported earlier this year, of the , direct green jobs promised back in , only , have actually materialised.We are now told therell be , new jobs in the great green rebuild. But where are they coming from  We may have % of Europes wind energy but it is being exploited by foreign state-owned companies, like EDF, employing workers in China, UAE, Indonesia ndash anywhere but Scotland. If the Scotland is incapable of exploiting our own environmental assets then people are going to ask: what is the point of leaving the UK What happened to the tidal power revolution in the Pentland Firth  That was what Alex Salmond was actually referring to when he first coined the phrase ldquoSaudi Arabia of Renewables ten years ago. The original Peterhead Carbon Capture and Storage project was going to use old mine shafts to sequester carbon dioxide. That was axed in  by the UK Government.Then there was Pelamis, which developed the first commercial wave power machine at the European Marine Energy Centre in Orkney. Gone. The UKs only wind turbine tower manufacturer, CS Wind in Campbeltown, effectively shut up shop in August.Few are aware that Scotland had one of Europes leading environmental bus manufacturers in Alexander Dennis in Falkirk ndash but not for much longer. The Scottish Government is very good at making bold pronouncements about net zero and banning petrol and diesel cars. But words are cheap.Where is the network of charging points for electric vehicles  What about replacing dirty diesel busses and trucks  Alexander Dennis designed clean hydrogen and electric buses, but has just axed  jobs.It rather looks asthe green jobs revolution is going to amount to more dodgy home insulation schemes, some trees, and a forest of green lobbyists surrounding shiny-bottom bureaucrats at interminable conferences on COP.We hear pious lectures from ministers about how we should be cycling and not using cars, while they travel around in their ministerial Lexuses. Local governments like Edinburgh are doing their best to reduce car journeys in the city through a campaign of permanent roadworks and guerilla pedestrianisation.Yet, bus travel has been declining fast, down % over the last  years, and that was before Covid. Until the pandemic, cycling was also in decline over the same period.Where is the smart public transport system with through ticketing and computerised, integrated rail and bus services  The only signicant urban transport investment recently was the ruinously expensive Edinburgh tram taking ldquohigh value folk from Princes Street to Edinburgh Airport.The Scottish Government will say that Scotland isnt an industrial powerhouse like America or China or UAE and cant just conjure dynamic world-beating industries out of thin air. Butthe nationalists cant deliver an industrial strategy that moves Scotland into the green age then their promises about an independent future may lack credibility. The Union didnt leave BiFAb on the scrap heap, it was an SNP administration wot done it.
